comments.commentBody:
I have to disagree Josh. US gas can't get to Europe for ten years, the time it takes to build the infrastructure on both sides, and the ships. Even then, the US would need to buy replacement gas, since we are a net importer, and would still be then. All this would accomplish is to push US gas prices up to world prices, to the benefit only of gas companies.

Meanwhile, Russia's pipeline to China is near finished. It may not carry it all, but in relative terms the Europeans would be in far more immediate and extreme hurt, and the US economy linked to them going down with them.

The Russians like the Middle East can't drink their oil, and they won't have to, because the rest of the world can't just burn its water. That gas would find a market sooner than Europe would find gas to replace it, much sooner.

This is no panacea for us. Calming ourselves with this imaginary scenario does nothing to help prepare for the real challenges we are facing.

This is too much like our calm assumption just before WW2 that the Japanese had no good airplanes, and no decent pilots either, and their ships were funny looking and top heavy and couldn't fight. Recall how that worked out.

We mustn't blunder into such arrogant false assumptions again. If we must face this, we must face it honestly, or suffer for lying to ourselves.

It's not a "handful." Often someone gets blocks of apartments and rents them out. During peak times, summer and holidays, I have been in the elevator with these visitors frequently, almost every trip, and I see them check into our lobby a few times a day.

Ross, none of this petty doctrinal stuff matters.

The same hierarchy that forbid the woman married to the divorcee from taking communion had no problem allowing child molesters to continue distributing it. To channel my inner Pope Francis, who are they to judge?

Moreover, if marriage were truly 'sacred' in the Church's eyes, then there would have been no annulments for anyone, no sophistic explanations of how Calista Gingrich was allowed to marry in church the extremely married knave whom she was committing adultery with during the Clinton impeachment.

Ross, between you and me, the Catholic Church should consider itself fortunate this woman still desires to partake in communion.

It's true, we had some patient care experience in med school but a lot of it was based on initiative and how eager the residents interns and attending were to let you try things (often not very willing because they were exhausted and wanted to finish things faster.) Internship and residency were pretty much like being thrown into the deep end. You had to learn to ask and improvise. Unfortunately, this was often balanced with trying to appear as if you already knew things which was part of the culture and could be dangerous if you were too proud to ask when it was important.  You were expected to learn things quickly... For new procedures-> "See one, do one, teach one".. a pretty steep learning curve.

Yes, of course utilities are forced to pay a premium for green energy, but we're paying/going to pay much more for the damage utilities are doing to the environment and in the absence of a carbon tax they *don't* pay for that.

As to "rent seeking," well, what's wrong with that? Those of us who believe in markets understand that markets work most effectively when price reflects cost. Right now, there are lots of subsidies, both hidden and overt, for fossil fuels. If we had a carbon tax, the cost of fossil fuels would actually reflect the cost of burning them and green energy would cost less, as it actually does. The market could then find the most cost-effective solution.

The only possible argument against a carbon tax is that it would reduce the profits of greedy sociopaths like the Kochs.
Prominent racists ARE newsworthy whatever South Carolinians may think.

Being a lifelong Montanan my only real exposure to racism is Native Americans. But there was a black family farming half mile north of us in the 60's when I was a kid. I played with their two young boys like kids do. Interesting that the youngest son ended up working for the same outfit I did later on.

I don't think racism will ever leave much of our country for several more generations, if ever. There will be times when it's put back under the rocks it belongs under. But all it takes is for a national political party and supporting media to bring them back out. And they have. I hope sensible citizens will shame them back under their rocks. But even then they'll come out now and then. I agree it was the election of Barack Obama who brought then crawling out in droves this time. I wonder when we might get a Native American running for congress in this state. I know a few that would be good in Washington DC.

The girl friend busted Sterling and he no doubt deserves it on all accounts. Legal or not. Was Mitt's 47% speech recording legal? Doesn't matter once it's in those internet tubes. Might hold up in the court of law but not the court of opinion and that's were politicians get their votes.

I'm struck by the vast difference in tone between comments on the Bundy story and this one. I wonder why??

Racism dead? Hardly. Not to suggest a great deal of progress hasn't been made if for no other reason than those don't get it feel the need to hide their true feelings. That's progress of sorts.

Bundy in Nevada and now this.

Is it because America has nothing better to be concerned about that this kind of personal speech, however much most may disagree with it, and with no policy implications by the government, is what the media become obsessed with and flog to death in the guise of debate? About what, and to what end?
Their mindset is encapsulated in how the CEO of Oracle so eloquently put it:  "it's not enought to win, all the others must lose."

Refusal to invest in something that won't pay off in one's own lifetime is one thing.  Trying to halt progress - or at least slow it down  - because long range benefit to the common good interferes with short term profit is the kind of greed that will never be satisfied. There is no such thing as "more."

Really?
WVC
He didn't just think it, he said it.  Big difference.

"What specifically has inspired this mass-hysteria of gratuitous--- unhinged, racism in America… exactly?"

I don't know for sure, but my guess is that the occupation of the "White" House by an African American family has a great deal to do with it.

ps: "divide and concur" Amusing Freudian slip or just a misspelling?
The racists are the old people. In general, the under 40 crowd is more accepting of different races, cultures, sexuality. Thank God. I wish it was my generation.

I hate to state the obvious: America is “Trending” racist.

And I suppose it could be argued that all of us are programmed throughout childhood with a predisposition--- somewhat biased inclination, to cohabitate with those who mirror our own self-image.

Yet, for one publicly embracing a more blatant bias, at what point has one to descend before being branded a diehard racist?”

Mr. Sterling has a Black-Mexican American girlfriend… a woman doubly-vested in his concept of “Melenated Peoples,” yet he laments that she wishes to associate with them-her people?”

What specifically has inspired this mass-hysteria of gratuitous--- unhinged, racism in America… exactly?

This unrelenting quest by the wealthy and right-wing political enablers to once again patronize racial animus as a means to “divide and concur” Middle America is both insulting and disgusting.

That's an America… today’s progressive nation yet stamped with the globally-revered imprimaturs of “Liberty and Justice for All,” the very antithesis of a nation that would endure or tolerate an imperialized racist subculture.

Seriously, is it conceivable… even remotely possible, a 21st Century socially-enlightened America which has elected its first African-American president might play coy with the mechanizations of stereotypes which birthed America’s brutally heinous Jim Crow era?

That would be insane… right?
Thanks for the interesting personal sidelight...

In the end, if we do not begin to deal properly with the budget we have, noone will escape suffering.  However, money does insulate from a lot of problems, and of course the poorest are always the most exposed.  Overpopulation and poverty force people to live in the most vulnerable locations.

What political party is that? The Democratic Party, which is the party that supported slavery, Jim Crow laws and racial discrimination. Oh I forgot; when someone makes a racially insensitive statement it is the Republican Party's fault.

I think such speech, reflecting said values, is regrettably commonplace, but more so amongst an older generation, who feel it may be ok somehow.    In this case, it is the disjunct between his expressed ideas and his position  as the leader of a public venture designed to unify people through a love of sport.  The thinking he has expressed is precisely the thinking meant to be overcome with integrated public sport teams.

This has nothing to do with freedom of speech. The government is not going to censor Mr. Sterling.  The 1st Amendment offers no protection with respect to whatever the NBA might do to him.   And, no, I haven't actually said anything similar to this in my life.
No. A great many of us have not "said similar, if not worse, things in our lives."

A mountain is made out a molehill. Americans have freedom of speech. Why could not this guy say whatever he liked in private, or for that matter, in public? What he said was not pleasant, but let's be honest. Have not we said similar, if not worse, things in our lives? Do not cast the first stone. Leave him alone. Do not let hypocrisy undermine our freedom of speech.

This man allegedly has a history of racist behavior.  These were allegations.  He also has a pretty stellar record of hiring minorities and keeping them in these positions even after they've demonstrated incompetence.  I think it is a stretch to say that the Supreme Court denies that racism doesn't exist (I think that is what you meant to say) and that Fox and the Republicans support the majority to be racist.  If that were true we wouldn't have a black President.
You are right, he sounds like the former Democratic governor of New Jersey, Jon Corzine, a member of the 1%, who was married with a mistress on the side.
This script makes perfect sense. The loudest voice in any American room is money. And a liberal Democrat is not necessarily enlightened -- dig Phil Ochs' song "Love Me, I'm A Liberal."

Nice to see that every so often Ms. Dowd can still get her mind off the insufficiently chummy Barack Obama and the excessively chummy Bill Clinton to aim her slings and arrows at something that's truly worth aiming at.  Even during the slowest of news-weeks there's always an outspoken Koch-head or an obtuse Tea Partier who's out to demonstrate that their "movement" hasn't hit rock bottom just yet.

Entirely accurate, Martin, and thanks for the info.

But if you had been trained to think like me instead of like JFC, you would have known that the answer to my specific question was, "Because he was paid by the word."

Isn't Ross DOTOAT the Op-Ed guy at the Times who gets the task of trying to explain ridiculous 21st-century GOP policies/politicians?
Was Mitt's 47% recording legal in FL?  Doesn't matter once it's out on inter-tubes.
A post racial society is a bit like Star Trek's post-money utopia.... In other words pure Science Fiction.
Bundy, now Sterling -- what happened to the post-racial society?

The best revenge the Clipper players can have would be to win the championship and when they hoist the Larry O'Brien trophy and Sterling tries to hold it, slap his hands away and tell him, "You didn't win this; WE did!"

Mark,

I think we could get natural gas to Europe much faster than that if we had to, in part by diverting supplies destined for Asia, in part by speeding the process. The Europeans could also move to alternate fuels and have untapped resources of their own.

The US is expected to become a net exporter of natural gas by 2020 and as things now stand, most of our imported gas comes from Canada, so there is no great hardship involved. As you point out, we pay much less for natural gas than the world price and while domestic prices might rise so would profits from exports -- something that is been known to strongly benefit national economies.

The Chinese pipeline isn't done and even if it were, Russia couldn't afford to lose its energy revenue. It's already in financial trouble with the ruble under pressure and the value of its bonds reduced to near-junk status -- and it was much poorer to begin with than the US and the EU.

So while I agree that sanctions would be costly for Europe and to a much lesser extent for the US. I think there's little question that they would have a much greater effect on Russia. It then comes down to a game of chicken: How far are the Europeans willing to go by way of economic sacrifice (since we are less affected than they are), and at what point does Putin conclude that Ukraine is worth more to him than sanctions. That last isn't easy to answer, since from Putin's perspective, Ukraine is worth an awful lot.
This is the guy who is about to be honored by the Los Angeles chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. with a lifetime achievement award?
Contracting African Americans to make money for you through their labor is not incompatible with being a racist.

If he really is the guy in the recording, it's pretty bizzare that he owns an NBA team since the league is dominated by African American players. That's why I'm waiting for the league to sort out this Cliven Bundy moment.
